DataElement.preferredDefinition: The code that describes the behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-2.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The behavior of the tumor being reported using ICD-O-2.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:Identified; having the identity known or established.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
The procedure of having an identity established.

Property.preferredName: Behavior International Classification of Disease for Oncology
Property.preferredDefinition: human or animal activity studied in terms of motivation, direction, result, emotion, perception, or etiology.:The International Classification of Disease for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com)

Concepts.definition: The actions or reactions of an object or organism, usually in relation to the environment or surrounding world of stimuli.

Concepts.longName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology
Concepts.definition: The International Classification of Diseases for Oncology has been used for nearly 25 years as a tool for coding diagnoses of neoplasms in tumor and cancer registrars and in pathology laboratories. ICD-O is a dual classification with coding systems for both topography and morphology. The topography code describes the site of origin of the neoplasm. The morphology code describes the characteristics of the tumor itself, including its cell type and biologic activity. (from Amazon.com)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredName: Behavior International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, Second Edition (ICD-O-2) Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The second edition of the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, published by the World Health Organization in 1992, and used for coding neoplasms between 1992 and 2000._A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual entities required by NCI operations and systems. Includes administrative, financial, organizational and quasi-scientific concepts required for NCI operations and systems.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, Second Edition Code
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The second edition of the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, published by the World Health Organization in 1992, and used for coding neoplasms between 1992 and 2000.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.longName: International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, Second Edition
Concepts.definition: The second edition of the International Classification of Diseases for Oncology, published by the World Health Organization in 1992, and used for coding neoplasms between 1992 and 2000.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Added reference document to ICD-O-2 to ICD-O-3 conversion manual, as it has a list of the ICD-O-2 codes/terms. DW 4-19-2017

ClassificationSchemes.longName: Division of Cancer Control and Population Sciences

ReferenceDocuments.name: Behavior (92-00) ICD-O-2 Description
ReferenceDocuments.description: NAACCR adopted ICD-O-2 as the standard coding system for tumors diagnosed from January 1, 1992, through December 31, 2000. In addition, NAACCR recommended that cases diagnosed prior to 1992 be converted to ICD-O-2.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Codes
ReferenceDocuments.description: See Behavior (73-91) ICD-O-1 [1972], for ICD-O-1 and field trial codes.  Valid codes are 0-3. See ICD-0-2,15 page 22, for behavior codes and definitions.
